## Table of Contents

1. Supplementary Text
2. Figures S1 to S5
3. Tables S1 to S3
4. Captions for Movies S1 to S2
5. Captions for Data S1 to S2
6. References (61–75)

## Supplementary Text

Use subheadings as needed (for example, "Study site", "Analytical pipeline", "Sensitivity analyses"). Keep paragraphs left-aligned with line breaks between them.

## Figures

Place each figure on its own page above the caption.

### Fig. S1. Descriptive title

Begin the caption with the figure identifier, followed by a concise description of panels and symbols.

## Tables

Each table should appear on a separate page. Keep wide tables as separate CSV/Excel attachments if they exceed the page width.

### Table S1. Summary statistics

Provide a brief description of the data shown and any abbreviations used.

## Captions for Movies

List media files included outside the PDF. Example: **Movie S1.** A 30-second time-lapse showing particle tracking (MP4, 25 MB).

## Captions for Data

Describe supplemental data files or archives. Example: **Data S1.** CSV containing raw measurements for Figures 2–3.

## References

Cite references in continuation of the main-text numbering, italicized in parentheses per Science Advances style.
